the_problem.text: The role of N95 respirators is to protect healthcare workers from exposure to airborne droplets by filtering the air being breathed in. In some situations, N95 respirators may be used for patient source control- to prevent contamination of the surrounding area when a person coughs or sneezes.

current_us_resources.text: There have been reports of N95 shortages at hospitals due to mask overuse by the public. Many hospitals are encouraging healthcare workers to find ways to reuse their current N95 masks. The global supply of N95 respirators has not recovered from the depletion that occurred during the initial outbreak of COVID19 in China.
'Huge shortage': Bay Area clinics seek supplies of masks for coronavirus
Coronavirus Prompts Hospitals to Find Ways to Reuse Masks Amid Shortages
Traders Seek China's Masks to Help US Hospitals Battle the Coronavirus

worst_case_expectation.text: "HHS estimates the U.S. could need up to 3.5 billion N95 respirator masks" over the course of a year in a pandemic (HHS estimate, Time) [3/10/20]

engineering_requirements.text: Proper fit to face; if a respirator does not fit properly, contaminated air can leak past the seal into the respirator
High particulate removal down to required PM size
Low cost and/or ability to sanitize

Typical US hospital practice would be to discard N95 after each patient contact.  CDC (Q&A in conference call) is suggesting in shortage to use same the mask for a series of respiratory patients.  Chance of transmission is low from the mask to patient, but care has to be take to avoid contact transmission by HCP from handling the mask.

assembly_fabrication_requirements.text: “MERV 13 or higher FILTRETE filters can be used to make DIY N95 masks”
